content.description: Start on the thin crack and move up to the first bolt. Grab for the rail and move up to the second bolt, follow the third bolt to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts and TR anchors. There is normally a rap ring on a piece off webbing on the tree atop this route, but when it was placed is unknown.
content.location: This is the second fully bolted route on the left face of Oz. It is just right of Scared Crow.

content.description: Follow up the center of the right face of Oz on cool features to a single bolt in the face. Top out the same as for Dorothy.
content.protection: Gear, a single bolt, and TR anchors.
content.location: Right of Dorothy, this is the center line of the right face of Oz. It is just below the single bolt.

content.description: This is one of Cape Ann's best crack climbs! Start below the crack, it may look a bit moist, but it can be easily be gotten around without getting wet. Start out as if you were going to Ruby Slippers, but take the beautiful, obvious crack of Tin Man to the top.
content.location: This is the obvious crack to the right of Ruby Slippers on the left face of Oz.

content.description: This is a great slab climb. Move up the thin crack from the bottom to the blank face and follow the bolts straight up.
content.location: This is the first fully bolted line on Oz, just right of Emerald City on the left Face.

content.description: Move up to the arete just left of Tin Man. Follow the bolts straight up  on thin features to TR anchors. Anything in the gully with the tree to the left is off.
content.location: This is the bolted arete right of the small tree in the middle of the left face of Oz.

content.description:
This is a great, hard, slab line.   

  Start on a thin flake system and follow the face up through thin edges and difficult smearing.  The crux is approximately halfway up moving through bad hands and worse feet.  The line seems to trend left slightly to a system of thin seams.   

  Someone has scrubbed the bottom a bit, but I recently cleaned this off and worked the lower section on top rope.  It is hard but seems doable in the 5.11 and up range.  The current condition of the rock does not help as the immediate surface is still a little friable and slippery after years under lichen.   It could use some heavy rain, another cleaning, and some sustained climbing.  It's a pretty cool line though and just needs a little love...if love is what you call it.
content.protection: No pro and setting up a top rope requires long slings.  There is a great spot for bolts at the top.
content.location:
This is the leftmost slab in the Oz area.  It should be pretty obvious because the cleaned swab through the center.  There is probably another line buried beneath moss to the left of this. 

  Given the amount of moss, this is a slab that clearly gets a lot water, so its condition will depend on its current level of use.

content.description: This is a great, little, chimney problem. Just step inside and wedge your way up. It is a little tougher if you have long legs.
content.location: This is right of the right end of Oz between The Man Behind the Curtain and Oz Boulder.

content.description: This is easy and fun boulder. I have never bothered to play on it myself, but I have seen many a chalky paw prints on this, so I figured it should be added.
content.location: Looking Directly at Oz wall, this boulder is on the far right. Its the last large chunk of rock of the area. Continue past Mand behind the curtain and Oz Chimney and you will see this boulder.

content.description: Move up the center past a broken bolt on the midsection of Oz. The crux is getting of the ground. There are TR anchors at the top.
content.location: This is marked by a broken, rusty bolt in the center of the bouldary middle section of Oz.

content.description: Move up the left arete of the middle section of Oz. There are TR anchors at the top.
content.location: Coming from the left face of Oz, you will see this big, bouldary type section just before the right face.

content.description: Follow up the left-leaning crack at the far right end of the right face of Oz.
content.location: This line is at the far right end of the right face of Oz.

content.description: Move up the right arete of the midsection of Oz.
content.location: This is the right arete of the bouldery section in the middle of Oz.

content.description: Take the chimney right of Tin Man to the top. It's a little strange and takes a couple weird moves, but it is fun nonetheless. There are TR anchors at the top.
content.location: This is the wet, mossy chimney next to Tin Man on the far right end of the left face of Oz.

content.description: Move up the left side of the face past a single blot toward the crack. Follow the crack to the top.
content.protection: One bolt on the bottom. Protect the crack with gear.
content.location: This is the first route on the left of the left face of Oz.

content.description: Follow the right-leaning crack to the TR anchors at the top.
content.location: This is the first line on the right face of Oz, just right of the Lollipop Gang.

content.description: Start with the good hold with your right hand. Work your feet up until you can match your foot to your hand and stand up. The rest involves a bit of slabby levitation using a few thin features to the top.
content.protection: A TR.  You could place gear in the Commander Salamander Crack if you were very ninja-like with your slab skills.
content.location: This is four feet to the left of the Commander Salamander Crack.

content.description:
Layback the short, widening finger crack to the top.   

  I cleaned this off thinking it would be harder.   It would be decent if it were twice as big; otherwise, I am not sure I would recommend it. There may be another short climb to the left of this.
content.protection: It could be bouldered, but it protects well with small gear (BD 0.5 and below).  This can also be led with just C3s.  TR anchors are finicky, but you can sling a boulder at the top with a long sling.
content.location: This little wall sits a little up and to the left of Oz itself on the uppermost cliff band.

content.description:
Oz is a great sport and trad area of Redrocks. Only 30 feet tall, it is short but sweet for slab and crack climbs. Also, it is a great alternative for when main crag is end to end with TRs. It is pretty shady here, but most of the rock dries pretty quick. TR anchors present fall of 2011. 

  There are also some awesome boulder problems that run across the top of this crag. Follow the trail marked with tape either from the left side of auntie em, or from the right side of the crag starting at oz boulder. 

Oz

  L->R: 

  Left Face   A. Commander Salamander Slab, 9, 1p, 25', TR.   B. Commander Salamander Crack, 6, 1p, 20', gear or TR.   C. Oz Slab, 11, 1p, 30', TR.   D. Emerald City, 7 PG-13, 1p, 25', bolt/gear.   E. Scarecrow, 9, 1p, 25', bolts.   F. Yellow Brick Road, 8+, 1p, 25', bolts.   G1. Ruby Slippers, 10+, 1[, 25', bolts.   G2. Tin Man, 8, 1p, 25', gear or TR.   H. Flying Monkey, 6, 1p, 20', bolts. 

  Center Arete 

  I. Munchkin, 9, 1p, 15', TR.   J. Oil Can, 11, 1p, 15', gear or TR.   K. Lollipop Gang, 8, 1p, 15', TR. 

  Right face   L. Dorothy, 6, 1p, 15', gear or TR.   M. Toto, 8, 1p, 20', gear and bolt.   N. Man Behind the Curtain, 6, 1p, 20', gear. 

  O. Oz Chimney, V0, 10'. 

  P. Oz Boulder, V1, 8'. 

  Close by to the north is the Down Under area.
